div1.p: Cooke describes the experiments at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Memorandum on yellow fever experiments, by Robert P. Cooke, [1940]
div1.p:
The experimental work with human material seeking
to discover through what means Yellow Fever is trans-
mitted, was initiated in early November 1900 by the Commission
headed by Major Walter Reed Med Corps U. S. A.

Shortly before this Dr Jesse Lazear, one of its four
member, died of the disease after allowing a mosquito
to bite him at San Lazarowrong P. S. H. hospital Havana.

In his memory an experimental Camp,
Staffed by Army personnel, was established on
a dry breezy elevation near Havana.

We were quartered in tents and quaran-
tined three weeks prior to the experiments. Temp-
eratures were recorded three times daily- All
remained well. Two buildings were
erected for formites and mosquito experiments
respectively the first was unretreated, except
for a small front window, and fenced in
with wire, A small stove kept the interior
heated to about 90° f, a maximum, and
minimum thermometer recorded the daily range
of temperature. Temperature's of the men were taken
t. e. d. The Cont. Surg. and two privates of the
Hospital Corps who entered this building were
the first “experimentees” in the camp and
were not allowed outside the enclosure for
three weeks , sleeping on army cots at night
and remaining outside during the day.
sheets, pajamas pillow slips and other material
soiled with discharges from Yellow Fever patients who
were ill or had died in Havana- were brought
to the Camp packed in boxes, on several occasions

Each night the men unpacked these and hung
them on and around their beds and, at times,
wore the pajamas- Meals were brought from
Camp and left outside-- No one was allowed
to enter the enclosure- There was probably
small tent outside- My memory as to this
is uncertain- Three details of men lived
in this building for 2, days each and no
ill effects were experienced with me
were Pvt's Warren G. Jernegan and Lev. E Folks
Hosp. Corps U. S. A. Both men are now dead.

To my knowledge none of the Americans
taking part in these experiments accepted
any kind of reward. Several Spanish
volunteers were, Dulin, paid $100 to $200 gold,
the latter sum if they took the fever. These were
all mosquito experiments or blood serum
infections- in which Americans also par-
ticipated. Cases of fever were transferred im-
mediately to the Post Hosp. Columbia Bks-
there were no fatalities.

The mosquito building was well ventilated and
divided by a wire screen- Both buildings
had double screen doors and windows
Volunteers sleeping for several nights on the
mosquito free side were unaffected while nearly
all on the side in which infected insects
were released came down-

We in the other building were awakened by
the Camp Surgeon about 2am on the
night when a chill signiled Kissingers at.
tack- All of us were considerably upset
thinking perhaps our turn would be next
This was the first controlled experimental
cases of record.

The present outer had no official
part in the conduct of their experiments
but rated only as “materials”.

It was horseder his duty to record temp
eratures in the building and of the men
taking part.
